newsitem.title: USA: Baton Rouge tollway may hinge on legislature.
newsitem.headline: Baton Rouge tollway may hinge on legislature.

text.p: Construction could begin next year on a bypass around Baton Rouge if the Louisiana Legislature approves a bill authorizing toll roads, the Advocate reported Tuesday.

Louisiana's House of Representatives has already approved a bill allowing private companies and public-private partnerships to build toll roads. The bill was also approved by the Senate Transportation Committee and is pending in the Senate Finance Committee.

It would let local governments create toll road authorities to build and maintain toll roads with private industry partners. The bill requires that a feasibility study and a financial viability study be completed before a local authority could be created.
Baton Rouge Mayor Tom McHugh told the newspaper that an engineering firm had already determined that a Baton Rouge bypass is needed and feasible.

The proposed bypass would begin at state highway 415 in West Baton Rouge Parish and loop south and east into East Baton Rouge Parish, connecting with Interstate 10 in or near northern Ascension Parish.
The road would cost $900 million to $1.2 billion. McHugh said a financial feasilility study was pending and that several firms were considering the public-private toll road concept.
City council members told the newspaper it was unlikely the road could be built with tax funding if the toll proposal fails.
